conclusion: Points A, B, and C are the vertices of an equilateral triangle.
Charges are placed at points A and B.
The electric field strength at the center O of the triangle is E.
The electric potential at infinity is 0.
The electric field at a point is given by the formula E = kQ/r^2.
Since the triangle is equilateral, the distance from any vertex to the center is sqrt(3)/2 times the side length.
The charge at point A is Q_A, and the charge at point B is Q_B.
The electric field at point O is the average of the fields at points A and B.
E_avg = (E_A + E_B)/2.
The electric potential at a point is given by the formula V = kQ/r.
Since the triangle is equilateral, the distance from any vertex to the center is sqrt(3)/2 times the side length.
The electric potential at point O is the average of the potentials at points A and B.
V_avg = (V_A + V_B)/2.
An equal-magnitude opposite-sign charge is placed at point C.
The electric field at point C is the same as the electric field at point A.
The electric potential at point C is the same as the electric potential at point A.
The electric field at point O is the average of the fields at points A and B.
The electric potential at point O is the average of the potentials at points A and B.
Electric Field Strength at Point O: E_avg = (E_A + E_B)/2.
Electric Potential at Point O: V_avg = (V_A + V_B)/2.
